awd_titl_txt: Multiphase Atmospheric Chemistry Impacts with PartMC and MultiChem
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on the development of a flexible modeling framework for multiphase atmospheric chemistry. The new framework has the potential for significantly decreasing the computational cost of atmospheric modeling and for improving the understanding of the role of atmospheric particles in influencing climate. This will be an important contribution to reducing the uncertainty in the predictions of future climate change, a subject of great impact for society.

The objective of the research is to understand how per-particle multiphase chemistry impacts aerosol mixing state and thus climate, with a focus on mixed organic/inorganic aerosols. The distribution of particle compositions and morphologies (the physicochemical mixing state) can impact gas-aerosol partitioning, chemical aging, and aerosol water uptake, and in turn, impact aerosol impacts on climate. The flexible modeling framework for multiphase chemistry (MultiChem) will be used within an ultra-detailed particle-resolved aerosol model (PartMC) and standard sectional/modal models in both box and 3-D regional simulations.

The science questions that will be addressed by this research are: (1) How is per-particle composition and morphology impacted by aerosol-gas phase partitioning of inorganic and organic species and the resulting changes to water uptake? (2) How do these impacts on per-particle composition and morphology propagate into aerosol climate impacts, in particular aerosol optical properties and cloud condensation nuclei activity? and (3) How do these impacts depend on meteorological conditions and the transport of particles and gases in the atmosphere?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project advanced the state of atmospheric modeling by developing a flexible, extensible framework for simulating gas- and aerosol-phase chemistry across spatial scales and model architectures. At the core of this innovation is an “abstracted aerosol representation” that enables a given chemical mechanism to be deployed consistently across different aerosol modeling approaches, including sectional, modal, and particle-resolved frameworks. This approach addresses a longstanding challenge in atmospheric chemistry modeling: the difficulty of translating mechanistic understanding across models with different representations of the aerosol population. By decoupling the chemical mechanism from the underlying aerosol representation, our framework allows chemical processes to be modeled more accurately and more consistently across applications ranging from box models to regional and global chemical weather prediction systems.

To facilitate widespread adoption and reproducibility, the framework was implemented using modern software engineering practices, including object-oriented design, runtime configuration via human-readable JSON input files, and automated unit testing. This design allows users to customize multiphase chemical mechanisms—including gas-phase and heterogeneous reactions, photolysis, emissions, and deposition—without needing to recompile the model. These capabilities dramatically lower the barrier to entry for researchers and educators, broadening access to state-of-the-art chemical modeling. The framework compiles as a standalone library and has been successfully integrated into two major modeling platforms: the particle-resolved model PartMC and the Multiscale Online AtmospheRe CHemistry (MONARCH) system. In these systems, we demonstrated that the framework enables sophisticated, mechanistic simulations of multiphase chemistry while maintaining computational efficiency and flexibility.

As a key outcome, this work also resulted in the development of PyPartMC, a Python interface to the particle-resolved model PartMC. PyPartMC streamlines the setup, execution, and analysis of particle-resolved simulations by eliminating the need for users to manually configure and compile Fortran code. With a single-step installation process using the Python package manager `pip`, users across major operating systems (Linux, macOS, and Windows) can install PartMC and its dependencies without requiring specialized computational expertise. PyPartMC integrates seamlessly with the broader scientific Python ecosystem, allowing researchers to run simulations, perform diagnostics, and visualize results within a unified programming environment. Moreover, because PyPartMC enables direct control over the simulation time loop, it opens the door to coupling PartMC with other Python-interoperable tools, such as data assimilation frameworks, optimization libraries, or machine learning models. These capabilities significantly broaden the accessibility and utility of particle-resolved modeling for a wide range of scientific and educational applications.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in the creation of a generalizable, mechanism-agnostic framework for multiphase chemistry modeling and its successful integration into multiple modeling platforms. This approach improves the physical realism of aerosol and gas-phase chemical simulations by better representing process-level complexity without sacrificing flexibility or scalability. It enables comparative studies across model types, fosters methodological consistency, and facilitates the integration of new experimental findings into atmospheric models. The development of PyPartMC further strengthens the impact by enabling computationally intensive, particle-resolved modeling to be more easily adopted by the broader research community.

The broader impacts of this work are significant. By removing technical barriers to using sophisticated modeling tools, this project democratizes access to high-fidelity simulations of atmospheric chemistry. This is particularly important for early-career researchers, educators, and those working in resource-constrained environments. The use of open-source tools and transparent, reproducible workflows encourages community engagement, fosters collaboration across disciplines, and enhances the potential for educational use. Several undergraduate and graduate students were trained as part of this project, gaining hands-on experience in scientific software development, numerical modeling, and atmospheric chemistry. PyPartMC, for example, is already being used to support graduate-level coursework and independent research projects. The improved flexibility in chemical mechanism design also makes it easier for experimentalists to test hypotheses and for educators to construct simplified models for teaching.

In summary, this project developed a modular, extensible framework for chemical process modeling that bridges scales and model types, integrated that framework into operational modeling systems, and broadened access through user-friendly, open-source tools. These outcomes advance fundamental understanding of multiphase atmospheric chemistry and enable the next generation of researchers and educators to engage with complex models in a transparent and reproducible way.
